so yt the Viper-catchers carried it with them 
out of town in Triumph never having experien 
ced before ye efficacy of their Remedy on so 
small an animal, <u>wch <\> as it receives the same 
quantity of venom by a bite as a larger one 
doth, is more liable to die under it & Keept it alive above 3 months when they killed it & eat it. They said 
yt they had experienced their Remedy to take 
effect on Cows, Horses & Dogs ten hours after 
[text?] being bit; but that for themselves who 
are frequently bit in ye feilds as they catch ye 
Vipers, yt they always carry a vial of <s>their Re-
medy <\s> Sallad oil along with them , that as soon as they 
perceive themselves wounded, they without any 
loss of time bath ye part with it, & if it be 
the heel they wet ye stocking thoro’ly with it 
if the finger, <u>wch <\u> happens oftenest they 
pour some of it into that finger of their glove 
<u>wch <\u> they immediately put on again & thus never 
feel any farther inconvenience from ye Accident 
not even so much as from ye sting of a comon 
Bee. <s>I wonder’d, on asking them yt they had not 
ever tryed their Remedy [text?] ye sting of 
a Bee, Wasp or Hornet, <u>wch <\u> in all proba 
bility it must [text?]; & <\s> per haps it 
may be found of use for ye bite of Rattle 
snakes & other venomous Animals especially
